Leonardo da Vinci: Bringing back Leonardo da Vinci would be a dream come true for art enthusiasts. He was a genius in his time and his work in painting, sculpture, and engineering still inspire people today. With his unique perspective on the world and his ability to think outside the box, he would bring a fresh perspective to our understanding of art and science.

Cleopatra: Bringing back Cleopatra would be fascinating for history buffs. As the last pharaoh of ancient Egypt, she was known for her intelligence, charm, and political acumen. With her return, we could learn more about her reign and her relationship with Julius Caesar and Mark Antony.

Martin Luther King Jr.: Bringing back Martin Luther King Jr. would be a powerful way to honor his legacy and continue his fight for equality and justice. With his eloquence and charisma, he would inspire a new generation of activists and leaders to continue the struggle for civil rights.

Albert Einstein: Bringing back Albert Einstein would be a boon for scientists and philosophers. He was one of the greatest minds of the 20th century, and his work in physics and relativity forever changed our understanding of the universe. With his return, we could learn more about his theories and his vision for the future of science.

Jane Austen: Bringing back Jane Austen would be a delight for literature lovers. Her novels, such as Pride and Prejudice and Sense and Sensibility, are still widely read and loved today. With her return, we could learn more about her life and her writing process, and perhaps even get a glimpse into her future works.
